sections.title: What is Timeout Memory?
sections.content: Timeout Memory monitors the update frequency of monitoring items and automatically sets a digital output based on whether the item is updating regularly or has stopped responding. It acts as a watchdog timer for data freshness.

sections.title: How It Works
content: Every second, the system checks the input item's last update timestamp
Output = 0: Input is updating within the timeout period (normal)
Output = 1: Input hasn't updated for longer than timeout (stale/failure)
Automatically resets when input resumes updating

sections.title: Communication Monitoring Example
sections.content:
Scenario: Monitor Modbus slave communication

Input Item: Temperature sensor from Modbus device
Output Item: Communication status indicator
Timeout: 60 seconds

Normal Operation:
• Modbus polls every 10 seconds
• Temperature updates regularly
• Output stays at 0

Communication Failure:
• Network cable unplugged
• Temperature stops updating
• After 60 seconds, output changes to 1
• Alarm triggers notification
• Output resets to 0 when cable reconnected

sections.title: Common Applications
content: Device Health Monitoring: Track PLC, sensor, and field device responsiveness
Communication Watchdog: Detect Modbus, BACnet, or OPC failures
Data Staleness Detection: Identify frozen or stuck measurements
Safety Interlocks: Stop processes when critical data becomes stale
Dashboard Indicators: Display real-time device online/offline status

sections.title: Configuration Guidelines
sections.content: Set timeout period 2-3x the normal scan rate to avoid false alarms. For a 10-second scan rate, use 30-60 second timeout. Account for network delays, system load, and startup time.

sections.title: What is the Input Item?
sections.content: The Input Item is any monitoring item (Digital or Analog, Input or Output) whose update timestamp will be monitored for timeout detection.

sections.title: How It Works
content: Every second, the system checks the item's last update timestamp
If the time since last update exceeds the timeout period, the output is set to 1
When the item starts updating again, the output resets to 0

sections.title: Common Use Cases
sections.content:
Communication Monitoring:
• Monitor Modbus slave connection status
• Detect PLC communication failures
• Track field device health

Sensor Watchdog:
• Verify temperature sensors are responding
• Check flow meter updates
• Monitor pressure transmitter activity

Process Monitoring:
• Detect stuck process values
• Identify frozen measurements
• Alert on data staleness

sections.title: Best Practices
sections.content:
• Choose critical items that must update regularly
• Consider communication scan rates when setting timeout
• Use for safety-critical monitoring
• Combine with alarms for immediate notification

sections.title: What is the Output Item?
sections.content: The Output Item is a Digital Output that indicates timeout status: 0 = Input updating normally, 1 = Timeout exceeded (input stale or not updating)

sections.title: Output Behavior
content: Output = 0: Input item is updating within timeout period (normal operation)
Output = 1: Input item hasn't updated for longer than timeout period (failure/stale data)
Changes immediately when timeout condition occurs
Automatically resets when input resumes updating

sections.title: Integration Examples
sections.content:
Alarm Integration:
• Connect to alarm system for notifications
• Trigger warning lights or sirens
• Send email/SMS alerts via alarm conditions

Control Logic:
• Interlock processes requiring live data
• Switch to backup sensors
• Activate safe mode when data is stale

Dashboard Display:
• Show communication health status
• Display device online/offline indicators
• Create system health overview

sections.title: Important Notes
sections.content:
• Output must be a Digital Output type
• Do not use the same item for input and output
• Consider fail-safe logic in downstream systems
• Test timeout detection before deployment

sections.title: What is the Timeout Period?
sections.content: The Timeout Period is the maximum allowed time (in seconds) between updates before the item is considered stale or non-responsive. When this period is exceeded, the output is set to 1.

sections.title: How to Choose Timeout Value
content: Consider normal update rate: Set timeout 2-3x the expected update interval
Account for communication delays: Add buffer for network latency
Balance sensitivity vs. false alarms: Too short = nuisance alarms, too long = delayed detection
Match to process criticality: Critical systems need shorter timeouts

sections.title: Typical Timeout Values
sections.content:
Fast Processes (1s scan rate):
• Timeout: 5-10 seconds
• Use for: Critical safety systems, fast control loops

Normal Processes (5-10s scan rate):
• Timeout: 30-60 seconds
• Use for: Standard monitoring, temperature control

Slow Processes (30s+ scan rate):
• Timeout: 120-300 seconds
• Use for: Tank levels, slow temperature changes

Remote Devices (variable network):
• Timeout: 60-120 seconds
• Use for: Remote sites, wireless sensors, cellular connections

sections.title: Configuration Tips
sections.content:
1. Start with conservative (longer) timeouts
2. Monitor false alarm rate over 24-48 hours
3. Gradually reduce timeout if needed
4. Document timeout rationale for future reference
5. Review timeouts during system changes

sections.title: Common Pitfalls
sections.content:
• Setting timeout shorter than normal scan interval
• Not accounting for startup/initialization time
• Ignoring network latency variations
• Forgetting about system load impacts
• Using same timeout for all items regardless of criticality

sections.title: What is Write Action Memory?
sections.content: Write Action Memory automatically writes values to output items at regular intervals. It supports both static values and dynamic values read from other items, with execution counting and interval-based triggering.

sections.title: How It Works
content: Monitors an input item to stay synchronized with system updates
Every N seconds (interval), writes a value to the output item
Value can be static (fixed) or dynamic (read from another item)
Tracks execution count and can stop after N executions
Calls Points.WriteOrAddValue which handles InterfaceType appropriately

sections.title: Common Use Cases
sections.content:
Periodic Commands:
• Reset totalizer counters daily
• Send keepalive signals to equipment
• Toggle outputs for testing
• Cycle pumps or valves periodically

Data Replication:
• Copy values from one PLC to another
• Mirror sensor readings to backup systems
• Broadcast values to multiple destinations

Scheduled Actions:
• Set operation modes at intervals
• Update setpoints periodically
• Refresh display values

sections.title: Execution Modes
sections.content:
Continuous Mode: Leave Max Execution Count empty. Writes will continue indefinitely every interval.

Limited Mode: Set Max Execution Count (e.g., 10). After 10 writes, execution stops automatically. Use Reset Execution Count in edit dialog to restart.

sections.title: Important Notes
sections.content:
• Output item must be DigitalOutput or AnalogOutput
• Type conversion happens automatically (value → string)
• For controller writes (Modbus/Sharp7), duration parameter applies
• Execution count persists across system restarts
• Consider network load when setting short intervals

sections.title: Purpose
sections.content: Optional human-readable name to help identify this write action in lists and logs.

sections.title: Naming Examples
sections.content:
Descriptive names:
• 'Reset Daily Totalizer'
• 'Pump 1 Keepalive Signal'
• 'Copy Tank Level to Backup PLC'
• 'Set Night Mode Every 8 Hours'
• 'Test Valve Cycle - 5 Times'

If left empty, displays as 'WAM-{id}' in the interface.

sections.title: What is the Input Item?
sections.content: The input item is monitored to keep the write action synchronized with system updates. Any item type (analog/digital, input/output) can be used.

sections.title: How It Works
content: System checks input item periodically (1-second cycle)
When interval time has elapsed since last write, performs write operation
Input item does not need to change - it's just a timing reference
Provides synchronization with system monitoring loops

sections.title: Selection Guidelines
sections.content:
• Use a stable, regularly-updated item
• Can be the same as source item (for dynamic mode)
• Doesn't have to be related to output item
• Often convenient to use a system heartbeat or clock item

sections.title: What is the Interval?
sections.content: Time in seconds between write operations. System checks every second whether interval has elapsed since the last write.

sections.title: Common Intervals
sections.content:
Fast Operations (1-10 seconds):
• Keepalive signals
• High-priority data replication
• Testing and debugging

Medium Operations (30-300 seconds):
• Periodic status updates
• Sensor value broadcasting
• Regular control adjustments

Slow Operations (600+ seconds):
• Daily counter resets
• Scheduled mode changes
• Long-term data archiving

sections.title: Performance Considerations
sections.content:
Very short intervals (< 5 seconds) on many write actions can increase system load. Consider:
• Network bandwidth for controller writes
• Database write frequency
• Overall system performance
• Actual requirement for update frequency

outputValueMode.title: Output Value Mode - Static vs Dynamic

sections.title: Two Value Source Modes
sections.content:
Static Mode: Write the same fixed value every time.
Dynamic Mode: Read value from another item and write it.

sections.title: Static Mode
content: Specify a fixed value (e.g., '0', '100', 'true')
Same value is written every interval
Useful for commands, resets, toggles
Simple and predictable behavior

sections.title: Dynamic Mode
content: Select another item as value source
Current value of source item is read and written
Useful for data replication, mirroring
Value can change between write operations
Source item can be any type (automatic conversion)

sections.title: Mode Examples
sections.content:
Static Mode Examples:
• Write '1' to reset a counter → Static: '1'
• Send keepalive → Static: 'true'
• Set fixed setpoint → Static: '75.5'

Dynamic Mode Examples:
• Copy temperature from Sensor A to PLC B → Source: Sensor A
• Mirror tank level to backup system → Source: Tank Level Sensor
• Broadcast pressure to multiple displays → Source: Pressure Transmitter

sections.title: Type Compatibility
sections.content: All values are converted to strings before writing. Digital items expect '0'/'1' or 'true'/'false'. Analog items accept numeric strings. Ensure source item type is compatible with output item type to avoid unexpected behavior.

staticValue.title: Static Value - Fixed Value to Write

sections.title: What is Static Value?
sections.content: A fixed value that will be written to the output item every interval. The value never changes unless you edit the configuration.

sections.title: Value Examples by Type
sections.content:
Digital Output:
• '0' or 'false' → Off/Low
• '1' or 'true' → On/High

Analog Output:
• '0' → Zero value
• '100' → Set to 100
• '75.5' → Decimal value
• '-10.25' → Negative value

sections.title: Best Practices
sections.content:
• Use simple, clear values
• For digital: prefer '0'/'1' over 'false'/'true'
• For analog: include decimal point if fractional (e.g., '75.0')
• Test value compatibility with target item before deployment

sections.title: What is Source Item?
sections.content: In dynamic mode, the source item is read every interval and its current value is written to the output item. This enables data replication and value mirroring.

sections.title: How It Works
content: Before each write, system reads current value from source item
Value is converted to string format
Converted value is written to output item
Process repeats every interval

sections.title: Common Scenarios
sections.content:
Cross-PLC Data Sharing:
• Source: Temperature from PLC A
• Output: Temperature display on PLC B
• Result: PLC B always shows PLC A's temperature

Backup/Redundancy:
• Source: Main pressure sensor
• Output: Backup system pressure input
• Result: Backup system mirrors main sensor

Multi-Site Broadcasting:
• Source: Master site production count
• Output: Remote site dashboard display
• Result: All sites see master count

sections.title: Restrictions
sections.content:
• Source item cannot be the input item
• Source item cannot be the output item
• Source item can be any type (automatic conversion)
• Consider type compatibility to avoid data loss

sections.title: What is Duration?
sections.content: Duration is a parameter passed to the Points.WriteOrAddValue function (default: 10 seconds). It's used internally for controller write operations and timing.

sections.title: When Duration Matters
content: Modbus/Sharp7 controller writes: affects WriteItem DurationSeconds
InterfaceType.None writes: not typically relevant
System uses this for write operation timing and queuing
Most users can leave at default value of 10

sections.title: Configuration Guidance
sections.content:
• Default value (10) works for most cases
• For critical controller writes, may increase to 30-60
• Must be >= 0 (validation enforced)
• Consult system documentation for specific controller requirements

sections.title: Two Execution Modes
sections.content:
Continuous (empty): Writes continue indefinitely every interval.
Limited (number): Stops after N successful writes.

sections.title: How It Works
content: CurrentExecutionCount starts at 0
After each successful write, count increments
When count reaches MaxExecutionCount, writes stop
Processor skips this memory once limit reached
Count persists across system restarts
Use Reset Execution Count checkbox (in edit) to restart

sections.title: Use Cases
sections.content:
Testing/Commissioning:
• Test valve operation 5 times → Max: 5
• Verify pump cycles 10 times → Max: 10
• Run diagnostic sequence 3 times → Max: 3

Scheduled Limited Actions:
• Send daily report for 30 days → Max: 30
• Periodic calibration signal 12 times (monthly for a year) → Max: 12
• Startup sequence repeat 3 times → Max: 3

Continuous Operations:
• Keepalive signals → Max: empty (continuous)
• Data replication → Max: empty (continuous)
• Status broadcasting → Max: empty (continuous)

sections.title: Resetting Count
sections.content:
When limit is reached:
1. Edit the write action memory
2. Check 'Reset Execution Count' checkbox
3. Optionally adjust Max Execution Count
4. Save

Current count resets to 0 and writes resume.

sections.title: What is PID Control?
sections.content: PID (Proportional-Integral-Derivative) is a control algorithm that continuously calculates an error value as the difference between a desired setpoint and a measured process variable. It applies corrections based on proportional, integral, and derivative terms.

sections.title: Key Components
content: Input Item (PV): Process Variable - what you're measuring
Output Item (CV): Control Variable - what you're controlling
SetPoint (SP): Target value you want to maintain
PID Gains: How aggressively the controller responds

sections.title: Temperature Control Example
sections.content:
Input Item: Temperature sensor (25°C current)
Output Item: Heating valve (0-100%)
SetPoint: 30°C target
Kp=5, Ki=0.1, Kd=1

Controller Logic:
• Reads temperature (PV = 25°C)
• Calculates error (30 - 25 = 5°C)
• Applies PID formula → Output = 65%
• Opens valve to 65% to add heat

sections.title: Getting Started
sections.content:
1. Select your sensor (Input Item)
2. Select your actuator (Output Item)
3. Set your target value (SetPoint)
4. Use Auto-Tuning to find optimal PID gains
5. Fine-tune based on performance

sections.title: What is the Input Item?
sections.content: The Input Item is the measurement sensor that provides the current value of what you're trying to control. This is also called the Process Variable (PV) in PID terminology.

sections.title: Requirements
content: Must be an Analog Input monitoring item
Should provide stable, accurate measurements
Update rate should match PID interval
Range should be appropriate for the process

sections.title: Common Input Items
sections.content:
Temperature Control:
• RTD temperature sensor
• Thermocouple
• Temperature transmitter (4-20mA)

Pressure Control:
• Pressure transmitter
• Differential pressure sensor

Flow Control:
• Flow meter
• Magnetic flow transmitter

Level Control:
• Level transmitter
• Ultrasonic level sensor

sections.title: Important Notes
sections.content:
Ensure sensor is:
• Properly calibrated
• Installed in representative location
• Free from noise and interference
• Appropriate range for the process

Poor sensor selection leads to unstable control!

sections.title: What is the Output Item?
sections.content: The Output Item is the actuator or control device that the PID controller manipulates to affect the process. This is also called the Control Variable (CV) or Manipulated Variable (MV).

sections.title: Requirements
content: Must be an Analog Output monitoring item
Should have sufficient authority over the process
Response time should match process dynamics
Range should be properly sized (outputMin/outputMax)

sections.title: Common Output Items
sections.content:
Temperature Control:
• Control valve (heating/cooling)
• VFD for fan speed
• SCR power controller

Pressure Control:
• Control valve position
• VFD for compressor/pump
• Damper position

Flow Control:
• Flow control valve
• VFD for pump speed

Level Control:
• Inlet/outlet valve
• Pump speed control

sections.title: Sizing Considerations
sections.content:
Output device must be:
• Large enough to handle maximum demand
• Small enough to provide fine control
• Not oversized (causes hunting)
• Properly tuned with outputMin/outputMax limits

Oversized actuators lead to unstable control!

sections.title: Control Authority
sections.content: The output item should have enough 'control authority' to affect the process. If the PID output can swing from 0-100% but the process barely moves, the actuator is undersized or the process has other dominant influences.

sections.title: Naming Your PID Controller
sections.content: A descriptive name helps you identify and manage multiple PID controllers. While optional, good naming conventions improve maintainability and troubleshooting.

sections.title: Recommended Naming Patterns
content: Process-Location: 'Tank-1 Temperature'
Function-Zone: 'HVA-Zone-A Pressure'
Equipment-Purpose: 'Boiler-1 Steam Control'
Loop-ID: 'TIC-101' (Temperature Indicating Controller)

sections.title: Naming Examples
sections.content:
Good Names:
• 'Reactor Temperature Control'
• 'Supply Air Pressure - AHU-1'
• 'Cooling Water Flow - Tower A'
• 'TIC-201: Feed Tank Temperature'

Poor Names:
• 'PID1'
• 'Controller'
• 'Temp'
• 'Test'

sections.title: Best Practices
sections.content:
Use consistent naming across your facility:
• Include process/location identifiers
• Match names to P&ID drawings
• Use standard abbreviations
• Keep names concise but descriptive

sections.title: What Does Disable Mean?
sections.content: Disabling a PID controller temporarily stops all control calculations and output updates while preserving the configuration. The controller is paused but not deleted.

sections.title: When to Disable
content: Maintenance: Equipment is offline for service
Seasonal Shutdown: Process not running (winter/summer)
Testing: Commissioning other systems
Manual Operation: Temporary operator control required
Troubleshooting: Isolating control loops

sections.title: What Happens When Disabled
content: PID calculations stop immediately
Output item is NOT updated (holds last value or operator sets manually)
Configuration is preserved
Can be re-enabled anytime without reconfiguration

sections.title: Important Safety Note
sections.content:
Disabling a PID controller does NOT force the output to a safe state. The output item will hold its last value or must be controlled manually.

For safety-critical processes, ensure operators understand the implications of disabling control loops!

sections.title: Alternative: Manual Mode
sections.content: If you need to temporarily override control but want to keep the controller active, use Manual Mode instead. This allows you to set a fixed output value while keeping the controller configuration ready for auto mode.

sections.title: What is Output Direction?
sections.content: Output direction determines how the PID controller reacts when the process variable differs from the setpoint. This is critical for system stability and depends on your process type.

sections.title: Direct Action (Heating) 🔥
content: Output INCREASES when below setpoint
Output DECREASES when above setpoint
Used for: Heating, Pressurizing, Filling

sections.title: Reverse Action (Cooling) ❄️
content: Output DECREASES when below setpoint
Output INCREASES when above setpoint
Used for: Cooling, Depressurizing, Draining

sections.title: Examples
sections.content:
Heating Tank: Setpoint 50°C, Current 45°C
• Direct: Output increases to heat up

Cooling Tower: Setpoint 20°C, Current 25°C
• Reverse: Output increases to cool down

sections.title: Important
sections.content: Incorrect direction causes instability! The system will drive away from setpoint instead of toward it.

sections.title: What are Control Modes?
sections.content: Control modes determine who controls the output: the PID algorithm (Auto) or a fixed value (Manual).

sections.title: Auto Mode (Automatic Control)
content: PID algorithm calculates output automatically
Continuously adjusts to maintain setpoint
Normal operating mode for closed-loop control

sections.title: Manual Mode (Override)
content: Output set to fixed value (Manual Value)
PID calculation disabled
Used for testing, commissioning, or emergencies

sections.title: When to Use Manual Mode
sections.content:
• Equipment testing before automation
• Emergency situations requiring operator control
• Commissioning and calibration
• Maintenance and troubleshooting

sections.title: Best Practice
sections.content: Always verify process stability before switching from Manual to Auto mode. Use bumpless transfer to avoid output jumps.

sections.title: What is Interval?
sections.content: The time between PID calculations in seconds. This determines how often the controller updates the output value.

sections.title: Typical Values
content: Fast processes (flow, pressure): 1-10 seconds
Medium processes (level, pH): 10-30 seconds
Slow processes (temperature): 30-60 seconds

sections.title: Examples
sections.content:
Water Flow Control: 2 seconds
Tank Level: 15 seconds
Furnace Temperature: 45 seconds

sections.title: Trade-offs
sections.content:
Shorter intervals: Faster response but higher CPU usage and potential instability.
Longer intervals: Lower CPU usage but slower response to disturbances.

sections.title: Recommendation
sections.content: Match the interval to your process time constant. A good rule: interval = process time constant / 10

sections.title: What is Output Range?
sections.content: The minimum and maximum values the PID controller can output. This defines the control authority and protects equipment.

sections.title: Common Ranges
content: Percentage: 0-100%
Current Loop: 4-20 mA (0-100 scaled)
Voltage: 0-10V (0-100 scaled)
Custom: Any range matching your actuator

sections.title: Examples
sections.content:
Valve Position: 0-100% (fully closed to fully open)
VFD Speed: 20-100% (minimum speed to full speed)
4-20mA Signal: 0-100 (scaled to current output)

sections.title: Best Practice
sections.content: Set limits to protect equipment (e.g., minimum valve opening, maximum motor speed) and prevent dangerous operating conditions.

sections.title: What is Dead Zone?
sections.content: A range around the setpoint where no control action is taken. This prevents excessive adjustments for minor deviations.

sections.title: Why Use Dead Zone?
content: Prevents 'hunting' - constant small oscillations
Reduces wear on actuators (valves, dampers)
Saves energy by avoiding unnecessary adjustments
Accounts for sensor noise and measurement uncertainty

sections.title: Examples
sections.content:
Temperature Control: ±0.5°C dead zone
  Setpoint 50°C → No action between 49.5-50.5°C

Flow Control: ±1% dead zone
  Setpoint 100 L/min → No action between 99-101 L/min

sections.title: Important
sections.content:
Too large: Poor control, setpoint never reached
Too small: Excessive actuator wear, energy waste
Recommended: 0.5-2% of measurement range

sections.title: What is Feed-Forward?
sections.content: A control strategy that anticipates disturbances and compensates BEFORE they affect the process variable. This is an advanced technique.

sections.title: How It Works
content: Measures disturbances (load changes, ambient conditions)
Calculates required output adjustment
Adds compensation to PID output
Reduces disturbance impact on process variable

sections.title: Industrial Example
sections.content:
Heat Exchanger:
• Disturbance: Inlet temperature drops 5°C
• Feed-forward: Increase valve opening +20%
• Result: Output temperature stays stable

Without feed-forward: Temperature drops, then PID reacts (slower response)

sections.title: Complexity Warning
sections.content:
Feed-forward requires:
• Accurate process model
• Reliable disturbance measurements
• Expert tuning knowledge

Most applications work fine with PID only. Leave at 0 unless you have specific expertise.

sections.title: When to Consider
sections.content:
Use feed-forward when:
• Disturbances are measurable and predictable
• Process has large dead time
• Tight control during disturbances is critical
• You have process engineering expertise

sections.title: What is Cascade Control?
sections.content: A control strategy where one PID (outer/parent) controls the setpoint of another PID (inner/child). This improves disturbance rejection and response time.

sections.title: How It Works
content: Outer Loop: Controls primary process variable (slower)
Inner Loop: Controls secondary variable (faster)
Parent PID output becomes Child PID setpoint
Inner loop reacts faster to disturbances

sections.title: Common Applications
sections.content:
Tank Level + Flow:
• Outer: Controls tank level (slow)
• Inner: Controls inlet flow rate (fast)
• Level controller adjusts flow setpoint

Temperature + Valve:
• Outer: Controls temperature (slow)
• Inner: Controls valve position (fast)
• Temp controller adjusts valve setpoint

sections.title: Benefits
content: Faster disturbance rejection
Better control of slow processes
Inner loop compensates for actuator dynamics
Improved stability and response

sections.title: Configuration Notes
sections.content:
• Inner loop must be faster than outer loop
• Maximum 2 cascade levels supported
• Requires dynamic setpoint (setpoint item)
• Tune inner loop first, then outer loop

sections.title: When to Use
sections.content:
Consider cascade when:
• Secondary measurement is available and faster
• Disturbances affect secondary variable
• Single-loop control is insufficient
• Process has multiple time scales

sections.title: What is Hysteresis Control?
sections.content: Converts the continuous PID output to an ON/OFF digital signal using two thresholds. This enables staged control of relays, contactors, or pumps.

sections.title: How It Works
content: PID output reaches HIGH threshold → Turn ON
PID output drops to LOW threshold → Turn OFF
Gap between thresholds prevents rapid cycling
Digital output controls relay, contactor, or pump

sections.title: Heating System Example
sections.content:
Output Range: 0-100%
High Threshold: 75%
Low Threshold: 25%

Scenario:
• PID output reaches 75% → Heater ON
• PID output decreases to 60% → Still ON (hysteresis)
• PID output drops to 25% → Heater OFF
• Prevents rapid ON/OFF cycling

sections.title: Common Applications
content: Staged heating/cooling (multiple compressors)
Pump control (ON/OFF based on demand)
Relay-controlled equipment
Backup systems (activate at threshold)

sections.title: Threshold Selection
sections.content:
Gap too small: Rapid cycling, equipment wear
Gap too large: Poor control, slow response
Recommended: 20-40% gap between thresholds

sections.title: Best Practice
sections.content:
Use hysteresis for equipment with:
• Limited switching cycles (compressors, contactors)
• ON/OFF operation only (relays, solenoids)
• Staging requirements (multiple units)

sections.title: What are PID Gains?
sections.content: PID gains (Proportional, Integral, Derivative) determine how the controller responds to errors. Tuning these values is critical for stable, responsive control.

sections.title: Proportional Gain (Kp)
content: Responds immediately to current error
Higher Kp = faster response, but can cause overshoot
Lower Kp = slower response, more stable
Primary tuning parameter - start here

sections.title: Integral Gain (Ki)
content: Eliminates steady-state error over time
Accumulates error history
Higher Ki = faster elimination of offset, risk of oscillation
Lower Ki = slower convergence, more stable
Set to 0 for pure PD control

sections.title: Derivative Gain (Kd)
content: Predicts future error based on rate of change
Dampens oscillations and overshoot
Higher Kd = more damping, sensitive to noise
Lower Kd = less damping, cleaner response
Often set to 0 for noisy processes

sections.title: Tuning Starting Points
sections.content:
Temperature Control:
• Kp: 2-10, Ki: 0.05-0.2, Kd: 0.5-2

Flow Control:
• Kp: 0.5-2, Ki: 0.1-0.5, Kd: 0-0.1

Level Control:
• Kp: 1-5, Ki: 0.01-0.1, Kd: 0-0.5

Pressure Control:
• Kp: 0.5-5, Ki: 0.05-0.3, Kd: 0.1-1

sections.title: Tuning Method
sections.content:
1. Start with all gains at 0
2. Increase Kp until steady oscillation occurs
3. Reduce Kp to 50-60% of oscillation point
4. Add Ki slowly to eliminate offset
5. Add Kd if needed to reduce overshoot
6. Or use Auto-Tuning for automatic calculation

sections.title: Common Mistakes
sections.content:
Too high Kp: System oscillates or becomes unstable
Too high Ki: Integral windup, slow recovery
Too high Kd: Amplifies noise, erratic behavior
All gains too low: Sluggish response, won't reach setpoint

sections.title: What is Derivative Filtering?
sections.content: The derivative term is sensitive to measurement noise. A low-pass filter smooths the derivative calculation to reduce noise amplification while preserving damping benefits.

sections.title: Filter Coefficient (0-1)
content: Alpha = 0: Maximum filtering (heavily smoothed)
Alpha = 1: No filtering (raw derivative)
Typical range: 0.1-0.3 for noisy signals
Higher alpha = more responsive but noisier

sections.title: Application Examples
sections.content:
Clean Sensor (RTD, high-quality transmitter):
• Alpha: 0.7-1.0 (minimal filtering needed)

Noisy Sensor (thermocouple, low-resolution):
• Alpha: 0.1-0.3 (heavy filtering)

Moderate Noise:
• Alpha: 0.3-0.7 (balanced approach)

sections.title: When to Adjust
sections.content: Start with Alpha = 1.0 (no filtering). If derivative term causes erratic output or noise amplification, gradually decrease alpha until output smooths out.

sections.title: Trade-off
sections.content:
More filtering (lower alpha): Smoother output but slower derivative response
Less filtering (higher alpha): Faster response but amplifies noise

sections.title: What is Slew Rate Limiting?
sections.content: Limits the maximum rate of change of the controller output per second. Prevents sudden jumps that could damage actuators or destabilize the process.

sections.title: Why Limit Output Rate?
content: Protects mechanical actuators (valves, dampers, motors)
Prevents thermal shock in heating/cooling systems
Reduces wear and extends equipment life
Smooths transitions during setpoint changes
Improves process stability

sections.title: Typical Values
sections.content:
Fast Actuators (electric valves, VFDs):
• 50-100 units/second (allows quick response)

Mechanical Valves (pneumatic, motor-operated):
• 5-20 units/second (smooth movement)

Thermal Processes (heaters, furnaces):
• 1-10 units/second (prevents thermal shock)

No Limit:
• Set to very high value (e.g., 1000) or max output range

sections.title: Setting Guidelines
sections.content:
Too low: System becomes sluggish, can't respond to disturbances
Too high: Defeats the purpose, allows sudden changes
Rule of thumb: Output should be able to change from min to max in 10-30 seconds

sections.title: What is Setpoint?
sections.content: The target value the PID controller tries to maintain. The controller adjusts output to keep the process variable (PV) at this value.

sections.title: Static Setpoint
content: Fixed value entered in configuration
Remains constant during operation
Simple and predictable
Good for steady-state processes

sections.title: Dynamic Setpoint (Setpoint Item)
content: Value comes from another monitoring item
Can change during operation
Enables remote control via HMI/SCADA
Required for cascade control
Useful for scheduling and ramping

sections.title: Use Cases
sections.content:
Static Setpoint:
• Maintain room at 22°C
• Keep pressure at 5 bar
• Fixed production rate

Dynamic Setpoint:
• Operator adjusts temperature via HMI
• Scheduled temperature profile (night setback)
• Cascade control (outer loop sets inner setpoint)
• Load-following applications

sections.title: Best Practice
sections.content: Use static setpoint for simple, unchanging processes. Switch to dynamic when you need operational flexibility or integration with supervisory control systems.

sections.title: What is Manual Mode?
sections.content: In manual mode, the PID controller is bypassed and output is set to a fixed value. This is essential for testing, commissioning, and emergency situations.

sections.title: When to Use Manual Mode
content: Equipment testing and commissioning
Troubleshooting control issues
Emergency override situations
Startup and shutdown procedures
Maintenance operations

sections.title: Manual Value Options
content: Static: Fixed percentage entered in configuration
Dynamic: Value from monitoring item (operator control)
Allows smooth transition between modes (bumpless transfer)

sections.title: Typical Scenarios
sections.content:
Commissioning:
• Manual Mode, Manual Value = 50%
• Test actuator response without PID

Emergency:
• Switch to Manual Mode
• Operator controls output via HMI (dynamic manual value)

Startup:
• Manual Mode during warmup
• Switch to Auto once process stabilizes

sections.title: Important Notes
sections.content: Always verify process stability before switching from Manual to Auto. Use bumpless transfer to prevent output jumps. Document manual mode usage for safety and compliance.

sections.title: What are Thresholds?
sections.content: Two setpoints that control when digital output turns ON (high threshold) and OFF (low threshold). The gap between them prevents rapid cycling.

sections.title: High Threshold (Turn ON)
content: Output turns ON when PID output ≥ this value
Set based on desired activation point
Typical: 60-80% of output range
Must be greater than low threshold

sections.title: Low Threshold (Turn OFF)
content: Output turns OFF when PID output ≤ this value
Creates deadband to prevent chatter
Typical: 20-40% of output range
Must be less than high threshold

sections.title: Sizing the Gap
sections.content:
Narrow Gap (10-20%):
• More precise control
• More frequent switching
• Suitable for: Low-inertia loads, robust equipment

Medium Gap (20-40%):
• Balanced approach
• Moderate switching frequency
• Suitable for: Most applications

Wide Gap (40-60%):
• Very stable switching
• Less precise control
• Suitable for: High-inertia loads, limited-cycle equipment

sections.title: Equipment Limitations
sections.content:
Consider equipment switching limits:
• Compressors: 3-6 starts/hour maximum
• Contactors: 10-20 operations/hour
• Solenoid valves: Higher frequency acceptable

Size gap to keep switching within limits!

sections.title: What is Dual-Mode Configuration?
sections.content: Many fields support both static (fixed) values and dynamic (item-based) values. This provides flexibility for different control scenarios.

sections.title: Static Mode
content: Value entered directly in configuration
Fixed during operation
Simple and predictable
Good for most applications

sections.title: Dynamic Mode (Use Item)
content: Value comes from monitoring system item
Can change during operation
Enables remote control and scheduling
Integrates with other systems

sections.title: Examples
sections.content:
SetPoint:
• Static: Always maintain 50°C

sections.title: What are Input Items?
sections.content: The analog monitoring items whose values will be averaged together. All items must be of type Analog Input or Analog Output.

sections.title: Requirements
content: Must select at least one input item
All items must be analog type (AnalogInput or AnalogOutput)
Items should have similar units and scale for meaningful averaging
More inputs provide better averaging but increase computation

sections.title: Common Use Cases
content: Multiple temperature sensors in same zone (redundancy/accuracy)
Parallel pump flow rates (total flow calculation)
Multiple production lines (overall average output)
Redundant pressure sensors (eliminate single point failure)

sections.content: Use outlier detection when averaging sensors to automatically exclude faulty readings!

sections.title: Requirements
content: Must be an Analog Output item

sections.title: Output Uses
content: Display averaged value on HMI/SCADA
Input to control loops (average temperature for HVAC)
Alarm monitoring on averaged value
Historical trending and reporting

sections.content: Create dedicated output items for averages (e.g., "ZoneTemp_Average") rather than reusing existing items.

sections.title: What is Processing Interval?
sections.content: How often (in seconds) the average is recalculated and written to the output item.

sections.title: Choosing the Right Interval
content: Fast-changing values: 1-10 seconds
Moderate changes: 10-60 seconds
Slow-changing values: 60-300 seconds
Statistical analysis: Match your sampling needs

sections.title: Performance Trade-offs
sections.content:
Shorter intervals:
• More responsive to changes
• Higher CPU usage
• More frequent output updates

Longer intervals:
• Lower system load
• Smoother averaged values
• May miss rapid transients
Start with 10-30 seconds for most applications. Adjust based on how quickly your process changes and system load.

sections.title: What is Minimum Valid Inputs?
sections.content: The minimum number of valid (non-stale, non-outlier) input values required to compute and write the average. If fewer valid inputs are available, the average is not calculated.

sections.title: Setting the Value
content: Must be at least 1 and at most the total number of input items
Higher values = stricter requirement for valid data
Lower values = more tolerant of missing/bad inputs

sections.title: Usage Examples
content: 3 sensors, minimum 2: Can tolerate 1 failed sensor
5 sensors, minimum 4: Requires 4 good readings
10 sensors, minimum 5: Can work with half the sensors

sections.content: Setting this too high may cause output to stop updating if many inputs fail. Setting too low may produce unreliable averages from insufficient data.

sections.title: What is Weighted Average?
sections.content: Instead of a simple average where all inputs have equal importance, weighted averaging assigns different weights to each input. Higher weights give that input more influence on the result.

sections.title: How It Works
sections.content:
Weighted Average = (w1×v1 + w2×v2 + ... + wn×vn) / (w1 + w2 + ... + wn)

where w = weight, v = value

sections.title: Use Cases
content: Sensor accuracy: Give higher weights to more accurate sensors
Importance: Weight critical measurements more heavily
Coverage area: Weight by zone size (large room = higher weight)
Reliability: Higher weights for proven reliable sensors

sections.title: What is a Stale Input?
sections.content: An input is considered stale when it hasn't been updated recently. This typically indicates a communication failure, sensor malfunction, or processing issue.

sections.title: Ignore Stale Inputs Option
sections.content: When enabled, stale inputs are automatically excluded from the average calculation. Only fresh inputs are used. This prevents old/frozen values from skewing the average.

sections.title: Why Ignore Stale Inputs?
content: Sensor communication failure: Don't use old frozen values
Controller offline: Exclude disconnected devices
Maintenance mode: Ignore sensors temporarily offline
Network issues: Skip unreachable devices

sections.content: If too many inputs become stale and you fall below Minimum Valid Inputs, the average will not be calculated and output won't update.

sections.title: What is Stale Timeout?
sections.content: The maximum age (in seconds) for an input value to be considered fresh. If an input hasn't been updated within this time period, it's marked as stale and excluded from averaging.

sections.title: Recommended Settings
content: Fast polling (1s): 5-10 seconds timeout
Moderate polling (10s): 30-60 seconds timeout
Slow polling (60s): 120-300 seconds timeout
Rule of thumb: 3-5× your expected update interval

sections.title: Setting Examples
content: Modbus sensors polling every 5s → 20s timeout
BACnet devices updating every 30s → 90s timeout
Manual entry updated hourly → 7200s timeout

sections.content: Set timeout longer than normal update interval to avoid false stale detection from temporary communication delays.

sections.title: What is Outlier Detection?
sections.content: Automatically identifies and excludes anomalous values that are significantly different from the other inputs. This prevents faulty sensors or measurement errors from skewing the average.

sections.title: Why Use Outlier Detection?
content: Automatic fault detection: No manual intervention needed
Improved accuracy: Bad readings don't corrupt average
Sensor redundancy: System continues with good sensors
Early warning: Identifies potentially failing sensors

sections.title: Real-World Scenarios
content: 5 temperature sensors: 22°C, 23°C, 22.5°C, 23°C, 85°C → Detects 85°C as outlier
Pressure sensors: 100, 102, 98, 101, 15 PSI → Detects 15 PSI as fault
Flow meters: All reading 50 L/min except one at 0 → Identifies failed meter

sections.content: Outlier detection requires at least 3 inputs. With very few inputs, be cautious as legitimate variations might be incorrectly flagged.

sections.title: IQR Method (Interquartile Range)
sections.content:
Uses the statistical spread of values. Standard threshold is 1.5 (boxplot rule).

• 1.5: Standard, moderate sensitivity
• 2.0-3.0: Less sensitive, fewer false positives
• 1.0-1.2: More sensitive, catches subtle outliers

Detects values outside: [Q1 - threshold×IQR, Q3 + threshold×IQR]

sections.title: Z-Score Method
sections.content:
Measures how many standard deviations a value is from the mean.

• 3.0: Standard (99.7% confidence), conservative
• 2.5: More sensitive detection
• 2.0: Very sensitive, may flag valid extremes

Detects values with |z-score| > threshold

sections.title: Choosing Threshold
sections.content:
IQR 1.5: Good for most industrial applications
IQR 2.0: Use when inputs have high natural variation
Z-Score 3.0: Best when data is normally distributed
Z-Score 2.5: For tighter outlier control
Start with IQR 1.5 or Z-Score 3.0. Monitor results and adjust if needed. Lower values = more aggressive outlier detection.

sections.title: What is Moving Average?
sections.content: Moving average is a time-based smoothing technique that calculates the average of recent values over a sliding window. It's used to reduce noise and smooth trend data.

sections.title: When Does Moving Average Apply?
sections.content: Moving average mode is automatically used when you have a SINGLE input item. With multiple inputs, the system uses multi-input averaging instead.

sections.title: Average Types
content: Simple Moving Average (SMA): Equal weight to all samples in window
Exponential Moving Average (EMA): More weight to recent samples, smoother
Weighted Moving Average (WMA): Linearly decreasing weights from newest to oldest

sections.title: Use Cases
content: Noise reduction: Smooth noisy sensor readings
Trend smoothing: Display cleaner trend lines
Signal conditioning: Prepare data for control loops
Dampen oscillations: Reduce rapid value fluctuations

sections.title: What is Window Size?
sections.content: The number of recent samples to include in the moving average calculation. Larger windows provide more smoothing but slower response to changes.

sections.title: Choosing Window Size
content: Small (2-5): Minimal smoothing, fast response
Medium (10-20): Balanced smoothing and response
Large (50-100): Heavy smoothing, slow response
Very large (100+): Maximum smoothing for long-term trends

sections.content: Start with 10 samples. Increase if output is still noisy, decrease if response is too slow.

sections.title: What is a Totalizer?
sections.content: A totalizer (or accumulator) continuously sums values over time. It's used to track cumulative measurements like total flow volume, energy consumption, operating hours, or event counts.

sections.title: Key Components
content: Input Item: Source of data to accumulate (Analog or Digital)
Output Item: Where accumulated value is written (Analog Output)
Accumulation Type: How values are summed (Rate Integration or Event Counting)
Reset Configuration: When/how to reset the accumulated value

sections.title: Flow Totalizer Example
sections.content:
Input Item: Flow rate sensor (10 L/min)
Output Item: Total volume register
Accumulation Type: Rate Integration
Interval: 10 seconds

Totalizer Logic:
• Reads flow rate every 10 seconds
• Integrates: Total += (Flow × Time)
• After 60 seconds: 10 L/min × 1 min = 10 L
• Writes to output item: 10 L accumulated

sections.title: Getting Started
sections.content:
1. Select your input source (sensor or signal)
2. Select output item to store total
3. Choose accumulation type (Rate Integration or Event Counting)
4. Configure reset behavior (Auto/Scheduled/Manual)
5. Set appropriate units and decimal places

sections.title: Rate Integration

The analog value is integrated over time
Result: Total volume, energy, or distance

sections.title: Common Uses

Display on HMI screens
Input to other calculations
Trigger alarms on thresholds
Export to reporting systems

sections.title: What is Interval?

sections.title: Choosing the Right Interval
content: Fast-changing rates (flow, power): 1-10 seconds
Slow-changing values: 10-60 seconds
Event counting: 1-5 seconds (must catch all pulses)
Operating hours: 60 seconds or more

sections.title: Trade-offs
sections.content:
Shorter intervals:
• More accurate integration
• Higher CPU usage
• More database writes

Longer intervals:
• Less overhead
• May miss rapid changes
• Coarser resolution

Balance accuracy needs with system load!

sections.title: Recommendation

Start with 10 seconds for most applications. Adjust based on:
• How fast your input changes
• Required accuracy
• System performance
• Storage constraints

Disable: Pauses accumulation, preserves value and configuration.

sections.title: Accumulation Types
sections.content: Determines how the totalizer processes input data to produce accumulated values.

sections.title: Rate Integration
sections.content: Integrates analog rate values over time using trapezoidal rule. Use for continuous measurements like flow rates, power consumption, or speed.

sections.title: Event Counting
sections.content:
Counts digital signal transitions (edges). Three modes:
• Rising Edge: Counts 0→1 transitions
• Falling Edge: Counts 1→0 transitions
• Both Edges: Counts all transitions

Use for discrete events like pulses, cycles, or activations.

sections.title: Choosing the Right Type
sections.content:
Rate Integration: Flow meters, power meters, analog sensors
Event Counting: Pulse counters, proximity switches, contact closures

sections.title: Rate Integration (Trapezoidal Rule)
sections.content:
For analog input items. Integrates rate values over time:
Total += (Rate₁ + Rate₂) / 2 × ΔTime

Provides accurate integration even with varying rates. Ideal for flow, energy, and continuous measurements.

sections.title: Event Count - Rising Edge
sections.content:
Counts LOW→HIGH transitions on digital input.
Use when: Events occur on rising edge (e.g., pulse flow meters, normally-low sensors)

sections.title: Event Count - Falling Edge
sections.content:
Counts HIGH→LOW transitions on digital input.
Use when: Events occur on falling edge (e.g., normally-high contacts)

sections.title: Event Count - Both Edges
sections.content:
Counts all transitions (both rising and falling).
Use when: Every state change is an event (e.g., toggle switches, AC cycle counting)

sections.title: Digital Input Baseline
sections.content: On first run, current digital state is recorded as baseline without counting. This prevents false counts from system startup or configuration changes.

sections.title: Reset Mechanisms
sections.content: Three independent reset methods can be enabled simultaneously. When reset occurs, accumulated value returns to zero and output item is also cleared.

sections.title: Auto Reset (Overflow)
content: Automatically resets when value reaches threshold
Use for: Cyclic counters with fixed display range
Example: 4-digit counter resets at 9999
Prevents overflow in limited-precision displays

sections.title: Scheduled Reset (Cron)
content: Resets at specific times using cron expressions
Use for: Reporting periods (daily/weekly/monthly)
Example: Daily production totals reset at midnight
Supports complex schedules (weekdays only, first of month, etc.)

sections.title: Manual Reset
content: Operator-triggered reset through management UI
Use for: Ad-hoc resets (batch completion, calibration)
Always available when enabled
Provides audit trail in logs

sections.title: Combining Reset Methods
sections.content:
All three methods can work together:
• Daily scheduled reset for reports
• Overflow protection at 1,000,000
• Manual reset for special circumstances

Each reset is logged for traceability.

• Flow/Volume: 1-3 decimals
• Energy: 2-4 decimals
• High-precision: 4+ decimals

More decimals = higher resolution but more storage.

Direct value editing is not allowed to maintain data integrity.

sections.title: What is Rate of Change?
sections.content: Rate of Change (ROC) calculates the derivative of analog values over time. It measures how fast a value is changing and in what direction.

sections.title: Common Use Cases
content: Temperature rise/fall rate (°C/minute)
Pressure change rate for leak detection
Level change rate for tank filling/emptying
Predictive maintenance alerts
Process upset detection

sections.title: Temperature Monitoring Example
sections.content:
Input: Temperature sensor (currently 50°C)
Output: Rate calculation result
Time Unit: Per Minute

If temperature rises from 50°C to 55°C in 2 minutes:
Rate = (55-50) / 2 = 2.5 °C/min

High alarm at 5 °C/min detects runaway heating.

sections.title: Simple Difference
sections.content: Calculates rate from first and last samples in window. Fast and simple but sensitive to noise. Best for clean signals with low noise.

sections.title: Moving Average
sections.content: Averages rate calculations across all sample pairs in window. Provides smoother results than simple difference. Good general-purpose choice.

sections.title: Weighted Average
sections.content: Similar to moving average but gives more weight to recent samples. Responds faster to changes while maintaining smoothing. Good for trending.

sections.title: Linear Regression
sections.content: Fits a line to all samples and uses the slope as rate. Most noise-resistant method. Requires minimum 5 samples. Best for noisy signals.

sections.title: Choosing a Method
sections.content:
Clean signal + fast response → Simple Difference
Moderate noise + balanced response → Moving Average
Noisy signal + smooth trend → Linear Regression
Balance of speed and smoothing → Weighted Average
The time window determines how much historical data is used for rate calculation. Samples older than this window are automatically discarded.

sections.title: Effect of Window Size
content: Smaller window (10-30s): Faster response, more noise
Medium window (60-120s): Balanced response
Larger window (300-600s): Smoother, slower response

sections.title: Sizing Guidelines
sections.content:
Fast processes (pressure, flow): 10-60 seconds
Medium processes (temperature): 60-300 seconds
Slow processes (tank level): 300-900 seconds
The baseline phase ignores the first N samples to allow the system to stabilize before calculating rates.

sections.title: Why Use Baseline?
content: Avoid false alarms on startup
Allow sensors to stabilize
Skip initial transient readings
Ensure meaningful calculations

sections.content:
Baseline = 5 samples, Interval = 10s
First 50 seconds: Collecting baseline (no rate output)
After 50 seconds: Rate calculation begins

sections.title: High and Low Rate Alarms
sections.content: Set thresholds for abnormal rate of change. High alarm detects rapid increase/decrease. Low alarm can detect stalled or frozen values.

sections.title: Hysteresis (Auto-Clear)
sections.content:
Hysteresis prevents alarm chatter by requiring the rate to drop below a percentage of the threshold before clearing.

Example: High threshold = 10, Hysteresis = 0.9
Alarm activates at rate > 10
Alarm clears at rate < 9 (10 × 0.9)

sections.title: Alarm Output
sections.content:
Connect to a Digital Output to drive alarm indicators, notifications, or control actions. The alarm state is written to this output:

sections.title: What is Schedule Memory?
sections.content: Schedule Memory automatically generates setpoints or controls outputs based on time-of-day and day-of-week schedules. Perfect for HVAC temperature setpoints, lighting control, equipment start/stop schedules, and demand response programs.

sections.title: How It Works
content: Define schedule blocks with specific days, times, and output values
System evaluates the schedule at your configured interval
Active blocks are applied based on priority (higher priority wins)
Holiday calendars can override normal weekly schedules
Manual overrides temporarily bypass the schedule

sections.title: HVAC Temperature Setpoint Example
sections.content:
Scenario: Office building temperature control

Schedule Blocks:
• Monday-Friday 6:00-18:00: 72°F (Normal Priority)
• Monday-Friday 18:00-22:00: 68°F (Normal Priority)
• Saturday 8:00-14:00: 70°F (Normal Priority)
• Default: 65°F

Holiday Calendar: Company holidays → 62°F
Manual Override: Enabled for late meetings

sections.title: Common Applications
content: HVAC: Day/night, weekday/weekend temperature setpoints
Lighting: Scheduled on/off for energy savings
Equipment: Start/stop times for pumps, fans, compressors
Demand Response: Pre-cooling, load shedding periods
Security: Access control schedules, alarm arming

sections.title: Output Item
sections.content: Select the Analog Output (for setpoints) or Digital Output (for on/off control) that this schedule will control.

sections.title: Evaluation Interval
sections.content: How often the schedule is evaluated in seconds. Lower values mean faster response to schedule changes but more processing. 10-60 seconds is typical.

sections.title: Default Value
sections.content: The value to use when no schedule block is active. This is the 'fallback' value for times not covered by any block.

sections.title: Analog vs Digital Outputs
sections.content:
Choose based on your control needs:

• Analog Output: For setpoints (temperature, pressure, speed)
• Digital Output: For on/off control (equipment start/stop, lighting)
The output type determines what values you can set in schedule blocks (numeric for analog, on/off for digital).

sections.title: What is Evaluation Interval?
sections.content: The evaluation interval determines how often (in seconds) the system checks the schedule to see which block should be active and updates the output accordingly.

sections.title: Choosing the Right Interval
content: Faster (1-10 seconds): Quick response to schedule changes, higher CPU usage
Typical (10-60 seconds): Balanced performance for most applications
Slower (60+ seconds): Lower CPU usage, acceptable for slowly changing schedules

sections.title: Best Practices
sections.content: For HVAC setpoints, 30-60 seconds is usually sufficient. For critical control applications requiring precise timing, use 5-10 seconds. Avoid intervals below 5 seconds unless absolutely necessary.

sections.title: What is Write Duration?
sections.content: The duration parameter passed to the WriteOrAddValue function when writing scheduled values to the output item. This controls how long the written value persists on the controller.

sections.title: Default Value
sections.content: The default duration is 10 (units depend on controller configuration). For most applications, this default works well.
Only adjust this value if you understand your controller's duration requirements. Higher values may be needed for slower communication protocols.

sections.title: What is a Holiday Calendar?
sections.content: A Holiday Calendar lets you define special days (company holidays, weekends, maintenance windows) where the schedule should behave differently than normal weekdays.

sections.title: How It Works
content: When a holiday calendar is assigned, holiday dates override normal schedule blocks
You can set specific analog or digital values for holidays
Leave unassigned if you don't need holiday-specific behavior

sections.title: Office Building Example
sections.content:
Normal Schedule:
• Monday-Friday: 72°F during business hours

Holiday Calendar (Company Holidays):
• New Year's Day, Christmas, etc.: 62°F (energy savings)

Result: On holidays, temperature stays at 62°F all day instead of following the normal schedule.

sections.title: What is the Default Value?
sections.content: The default value is the 'fallback' output when no schedule block is currently active. It ensures the output always has a defined value.

sections.title: When is the Default Value Used?
content: During time periods not covered by any schedule block
When all schedule blocks are disabled
As the initial value before the first block becomes active

sections.title: For Digital Outputs
sections.content:
Toggle ON (true) or OFF (false) for the default state. Common choices:
• ON: For normally-running equipment
• OFF: For equipment that should be off by default

sections.title: For Analog Outputs
sections.content:
Enter the numeric setpoint value to use as default. Common examples:
• HVAC: Nighttime/unoccupied setpoint (e.g., 65°F)
• Lighting: Minimum brightness level
• Pressure: Safe operating pressure
Choose a safe, energy-efficient default value. For HVAC, this is often the unoccupied/setback temperature. For equipment, this is typically the OFF state unless safety requires it to run.

sections.title: What are Schedule Blocks?
sections.content: Schedule blocks define when specific output values should be active. Each block specifies a day of week, time range, priority, and the value to output during that period.

sections.title: Priority Resolution
content: When multiple blocks overlap in time, the highest priority wins
Critical > High > Normal > Low
Use higher priorities for exceptions and overrides
Same-priority overlaps should be avoided

sections.title: Overlapping Blocks Example
sections.content:
Regular Hours (Normal Priority):
• Monday-Friday 8:00-17:00: 72°F

Meeting Room Override (High Priority):
• Wednesday 14:00-16:00: 70°F

Result: On Wednesday at 15:00, the temperature will be 70°F because the meeting room block has higher priority.

sections.title: Manual Override
sections.content: Manual override allows operators to temporarily bypass the schedule. Useful for unexpected events, late meetings, or emergency situations.

sections.title: Expiration Modes
content: Time-Based: Override expires after the specified duration (e.g., 60 minutes)
Event-Based: Override expires when the next schedule transition occurs

sections.content: Remember that active overrides bypass ALL schedule logic, including holiday calendars. Use sparingly and monitor for forgotten overrides.

sections.title: Use Case: Redundant Sensors

For critical measurements, use 3 sensors with 2-out-of-3 voting. This provides:
• Fault tolerance (one sensor can fail)
• Eliminates single point of failure
• Common in safety systems (SIL-rated)

sections.title: Common Patterns
content: 1-out-of-N: ANY input satisfies condition (most sensitive)
N-out-of-N: ALL inputs must satisfy condition (most strict)
2-out-of-3: Classic redundancy voting (balanced)

sections.title: Example: 2-out-of-3 Temperature Safety
sections.content:
3 temperature sensors, require 2 to read > 80°C
• If one sensor fails high: Still safe (only 1 vote)
• If one sensor fails low: Still triggers (2 good sensors vote)
• Provides fault tolerance in both directions

sections.title: Operators
content: Equal (=): Value equals threshold (within hysteresis band)
Not Equal (≠): Value differs from threshold
Greater Than (>): Value exceeds threshold
Less Than (<): Value is below threshold
Between: Value is within two thresholds

sections.content: For temperature high alarms, use 'Greater Than'. For level low alarms, use 'Less Than'.
The numeric value to compare against. For 'Greater Than', values above this threshold satisfy the condition.

sections.title: Example
sections.content:
For temperature > 80°C alarm:

sections.title: Example

sections.title: How It Works
content: For 'Greater Than' with threshold=100 and hysteresis=5:
Turns ON when value > 105 (threshold + hysteresis)
Turns OFF when value < 95 (threshold - hysteresis)
Values between 95-105 maintain current state

sections.content: Use hysteresis to prevent 'flapping' of outputs when sensor values fluctuate near thresholds.

sections.title: Options

Turns ON when votes >= 3 (required + hysteresis)
Turns OFF when votes < 1 (required - hysteresis)
Once ON, stays ON until votes drop significantly

sections.content: Ensure requiredVotes + votingHysteresis doesn't exceed total inputs, or the condition can never turn ON.

sections.content: Shorter intervals provide faster response but increase processing load. Match the interval to your process dynamics.
Define aliases for input items to use in your condition expressions. Each variable maps a short name (alias) to a monitoring item.

sections.title: How Variables Work
content: Create alias: v1 → Temperature Sensor
Create alias: v2 → Pressure Sensor
Use in conditions: [v1] >= 50 && [v2] < 100

sections.title: Variable Naming
sections.content:
temp → Temperature reading
pres → Pressure reading
flow → Flow rate
level → Tank level

sections.title: Best Practices
sections.content:
Use short, meaningful alias names.
Avoid special characters except underscore.
Don't use the output item as an input variable.
Branches define the IF/ELSE IF conditions and their corresponding output values. Conditions are evaluated in order from top to bottom.

sections.title: Evaluation Order
content: First branch: IF condition
Subsequent branches: ELSE IF conditions
Default: ELSE value when no condition matches

sections.title: Order Matters
sections.content: The first matching condition wins. Place more specific conditions before general ones.
Write conditions using NCalc expression syntax. Reference variables using [alias] format.

sections.title: Available Operators
content: >= (greater than or equal)
<= (less than or equal)
> (greater than)
< (less than)
== (equal to)
!= (not equal to)
&& (logical AND)
|| (logical OR)
! (logical NOT)

sections.title: Testing Conditions
sections.content: Use the test button to validate your condition syntax before saving. Invalid expressions will show an error message.
The value to write to the output item when this branch's condition evaluates to true.

sections.title: Digital vs Analog
content: Digital: Typically 0 or 1
Analog: Any numeric value (integers or decimals)

sections.content:
Alarm levels: 0=Normal, 1=Warning, 2=Alarm, 3=Critical
Setpoints: 25.5, 30.0, 35.0 degrees
Hysteresis prevents rapid switching when a value oscillates around a threshold. It creates a deadband around the condition threshold.

sections.title: How It Works
sections.content:
If condition threshold is 50 with hysteresis 5:
• Activates when value rises above 50
• Deactivates only when value falls below 45

sections.title: When to Use
sections.content: Use hysteresis for noisy signals or when you want to prevent rapid on/off cycling. Set to 0 to disable.
The value to write when none of the IF/ELSE IF conditions match. This is equivalent to the ELSE clause in programming.

IF [temp] >= 80 → 3 (High)
ELSE IF [temp] >= 50 → 2 (Medium)
ELSE IF [temp] >= 30 → 1 (Low)
ELSE → 0 (Default - None of the above)
Always set a sensible default value as a fallback state.
When disabled, the IF Memory stops evaluating conditions and writing to the output. The output item retains its last value.
Use this to temporarily pause the conditional logic without deleting the configuration.

sections.title: What is Deadband Memory?
sections.content:
Deadband Memory filters out small, insignificant changes in input values to reduce output chatter. It supports two modes based on input type:

• Analog inputs: Value-based deadband filtering
• Digital inputs: Time-based stability filtering

sections.title: Common Use Cases
content: Noise filtering on sensor values
Prevent relay chatter from noisy digital signals
Smooth control actions
Reduce database writes from frequently changing values
Communication optimization

sections.content: A descriptive name to identify this deadband memory configuration.

The source item to monitor. The type determines the filtering mode:

• Analog Input: Uses value-based deadband
• Digital Input: Uses time-based stability filtering

The destination item where filtered values are written. Must match the input type:

• Analog Input → Analog Output
• Digital Input → Digital Output
How often (in seconds) the input is sampled and evaluated. Typical values: 1-10 seconds.

sections.title: Absolute
sections.content:
Value change must exceed deadband amount in engineering units.
Example: Deadband=2 means changes less than 2 units are ignored.

sections.title: Percentage
sections.content:
Value change must exceed percentage of input range.
Example: 5% of 0-100 range = 5 units deadband.

sections.title: Rate of Change
sections.content:
Change rate (per second) must exceed threshold to update output.
Example: 1.0/s means value must change >1 unit per second.

The threshold for filtering changes:

• Absolute: Engineering units (e.g., 2.5 degrees)
• Percentage: Percent of range (e.g., 5%)
• Rate of Change: Units per second (e.g., 1.0/s)
Used for Percentage mode to calculate the actual deadband threshold from the input range.
Used for Percentage mode to calculate the actual deadband threshold from the input range.

For digital inputs, the new state must remain stable for this duration (in seconds) before being accepted.

Example: StabilityTime=2.0 means a button press must be held for 2 seconds.

sections.title: Debouncing
sections.content: This is equivalent to debouncing in electronics. Use 0.1-0.5s for buttons, 1-5s for noisy digital signals.

sections.content: Min/Max Selector Memory outputs the highest or lowest value from 2-16 analog inputs. It's ideal for redundant sensor selection, lead-lag control, and safety-critical applications.

sections.title: Common Use Cases
content: Lead-lag pump control: Select the pump with lowest runtime
Temperature zone control: Select highest/lowest zone temperature
Redundant sensor selection (TMR): Pick the median or extreme value
Load balancing: Select least loaded equipment
Safety selection: Always use the most conservative value

sections.content: Bad inputs are automatically detected via quality flags and value validity. Configure failover mode to handle all-bad scenarios.
Select between 2 and 16 analog input items to compare. The selector will continuously monitor all inputs and output the selected value based on the selection mode.

sections.title: Requirements
content: All inputs must be Analog type
Inputs are evaluated at each interval
Bad/invalid inputs are automatically excluded from selection

sections.title: Example Configurations
content: 2 inputs: Hot standby sensor redundancy
3 inputs: Triple Modular Redundancy (TMR)
8 inputs: Select from multiple zones or equipment

sections.title: Minimum
sections.content: Outputs the lowest valid value among all good inputs. Use for selecting coolest temperature, lowest pressure, or least loaded equipment.

sections.title: Maximum
sections.content: Outputs the highest valid value among all good inputs. Use for selecting hottest temperature, highest level, or peak demand.
For safety applications, choose the mode that selects the most conservative (safest) value.
Determines the behavior when all input values are bad or invalid.

sections.title: Ignore Bad
sections.content: When all inputs are bad, the output remains at its last value but is marked as bad quality. No special fallback logic is applied.

sections.title: Fallback to Opposite
sections.content: If the selected mode (min or max) has no valid inputs, try the opposite selection. Example: If looking for minimum but all minimums are bad, try maximum. Useful for systems where any valid reading is better than none.

sections.title: Hold Last Good
sections.content: When all inputs are bad, maintain the last successfully selected value with good quality. Use when continuity is more important than accuracy.
Choose Hold Last Good carefully - the output may not reflect current conditions during prolonged failures.
Optionally output which input (1-16) was selected. This is useful for monitoring, alarming, or lead-lag tracking.

sections.title: Use Cases
content: Track which pump is currently lead in a lead-lag system
Monitor which sensor is being used in a redundant setup
Log zone selection for analysis

sections.content: The index is 1-based. Value 1 means the first input is selected, value 2 means the second input, etc.
The duration parameter is passed to the WriteOrAddValue function when writing the selected value to output items. This controls how long the write persists in controller write operations.

sections.title: Default Value
sections.content: Default is 10 seconds, which is suitable for most scenarios. Increase for slower controller response times.
